chapterMeaning: The Yoga of the Division between the Divine and Demoniac Qualities
sanskrit:
अहिंसा सत्यमक्रोधस्त्यागः शान्तिरपैशुनम् ।
दया भूतेष्वलोलुप्त्वं मार्दवं ह्रीरचापलम् ॥
transliteration:
ahiṁsā satyam akrodhas tyāgaḥ śāntir apaiśunam |
dayā bhūteṣv aloluptvaṁ mārdavaṁ hrīr acāpalam ||
translation: Non-violence, truthfulness, absence of anger, renunciation, tranquility, absence of slander, compassion toward all beings, non-covetousness, gentleness, modesty, and absence of fickleness.
commentary:
This verse continues the enumeration of divine qualities (daivī sampad) that Krishna began in the previous verse. These twelve virtues represent the ethical and moral foundation of spiritual life. Ahiṁsā (non-violence) heads the list as it is considered the supreme dharma, encompassing not just physical non-harm but also refraining from causing mental and emotional injury to others. Satya (truthfulness) and akrodha (absence of anger) form the basis of harmonious relationships. Tyāga (renunciation) refers to the spirit of letting go of selfish attachments, while śānti (tranquility) indicates inner peace that comes from self-control.

The remaining qualities address interpersonal conduct and inner refinement. Apaiśunam (absence of slander or fault-finding) and dayā (compassion) cultivate positive relationships with all beings. Aloluptva (non-covetousness) frees one from excessive desires for sensory pleasures. Mārdava (gentleness or softness of nature) makes one approachable and kind. Hrī (modesty or sense of shame regarding wrong actions) acts as an internal moral compass, while acāpalam (steadiness or absence of fickleness) ensures consistency in one's spiritual practice and character. Together, these qualities prepare the aspirant for higher spiritual realization by purifying the mind and establishing ethical excellence.
speaker: Krishna
